user_message:
<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 2.1 is: A project shall not contain unreachable code.

</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of MHD_socket_nonblocking_:
```c
int
MHD_socket_nonblocking_ (MHD_socket sock)
{
#if defined(MHD_POSIX_SOCKETS)
  int flags;

  flags = fcntl (sock,
                 F_GETFL);
  if (-1 == flags)
    return 0;

  if ( ((flags | O_NONBLOCK) != flags) &&
       (0 != fcntl (sock,
                    F_SETFL,
                    flags | O_NONBLOCK)) )
    return 0;
#elif defined(MHD_WINSOCK_SOCKETS)
  unsigned long flags = 1;

  if (0 != ioctlsocket (sock,
                        (int) FIONBIO,
                        &flags))
    return 0;
#endif /* MHD_WINSOCK_SOCKETS */
  return ! 0;
}
```
</target_code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
#elif defined(MHD_WINSOCK_SOCKETS)
  unsigned long flags = 1;

  if (0 != ioctlsocket (sock,
                        (int) FIONBIO,
                        &flags))
    return 0;
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 2.1 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: No violation. The fragment is inside an #elif defined(MHD_WINSOCK_SOCKETS) block so it is compiled and reachable when MHD_WINSOCK_SOCKETS is defined. The control flow inside the fragment is reachable: ioctlsocket(...) either returns non‑zero (causing the if to execute return 0) or returns zero and execution continues to the function's final return. There are no statements that can never be executed. (A violation would occur only if code were present in the compiled translation unit that can never be executed at run time, e.g. code placed after an unconditional return within the same compilation branch or a branch that is never compiled in any build configuration — neither is the case here.)
